title: Ensure updating the NXM links will not break Vortex
body:
**Describe the bug**
Currently, several NXM links use a different ID to the game domain found on the website. 

| Game | Game ID | NXM ID |
|--------|--------|--------|
| Skyrim SE| `skyrimspecialedition` | `SkyrimSE` |
| Fallout NV | `newvegas` | `falloutnv` | 
| TESO | `elderscrollsonline` | `teso` |

Related: https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/blob/cb3cc4486c5ac7cd33871970f4eb0902120dc594/src/extensions/nexus_integration/util/convertGameId.ts#L31

We want to correct these, but ensure this doesn't prevent the application from processing NXM links for these games. 

**To Reproduce**
Inspect the NXM link for any of the games mentioned above.

**Expected behaviour**
The downloads continue to work if these IDs are changed to align with the game domain.

title: FEATURE REQUEST - Option to Start a Tool with the Game
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I have an AutoHotkey mod that I converted to exe for Horizon Forbidden West. I added it as a tool in Vortex, but I still need to remember to start it when I launch the game, otherwise it won't work. This got me thinking...

**Describe the solution you'd like**
An option for Tools added to Vortex to launch the tool when the game is launched would be awesome. This would be very useful and allow users and extension authors to open up additional convenient functions for games.

title: maxMemory doesn't work as commandline argument or as startup.json parameter
body:
**Describe the bug**
The code indicates that it processes either --maxMemory or --max-memory as a command line argument. Also, there's some evidence that maxMemory is also parsed from startup.json. However, none of these options works, and the app crashes when I use 4k texture packs for rdr2 and click deploy mods with error memory usage growing fast {"usage":"3.74 GB","previous":"3.63 GB","max":"4.00 GB"}
2024-09-12T14:20:40.860Z [ERROR] render process gone {"exitCode":134,"reason":"crashed"}. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. install AIO Megapacks for RDR2 using Vortex
2. In shortcut to Vortex.exe pass command line args --max-memory 8192 --maxMemory 8192
3. For added measure, also add "maxMemory":"8192" pair to startup.json found in C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Vortex
4. deploy mods and wait. The app will keep crashing, saying it's using too much memory (vortex.log) , e.g. >= 4GB

**Expected behavior**
The user should be able to set the maximum memory to avoid the crash above. 

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Vortex Version 1.12.4

title: Feature Request - Toggle Specific Mods Checking for Updates ON/OFF
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I have a mod that has been updated, but the update has a bug that makes the mod unusable. Every time I check for updates in Vortex, I have to select "Ignore Update" in the context menu for that mod (This function was added using "Clear Update" extension) to remove it from the "Update available" list. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like an option added to the context menu to toggle update checks ON and OFF for specific mods. That way, I avoid seeing updates for that mod.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative now is to manually ignore the update every time. 

**Additional context**
N/A

title: Add an option to check for game executable to be present before doing anything
body:
So, when Vortex starts it checks for the game executable and if it's not present, manager just removes all mods and a setup (!)

It would be better to just not launch the mod manager or at least ask for some confirmation before removing mods.

How this could happen?

While Steam was updating Starfield i started Vortex and was updating mods as well to a new version of the game (like sfse, address lib, etc). So i selected desired versions of some mods and closed Vortex. Then i decided to change a bit more and opened it again. Meanwhile, Steam deleted executable for a patching process (and it's not like it's hardly reproducible if you launch at exact same second, no, executable was missing for quite a long time). So Vortex told me it couldn't find the game because Starfield.exe is missing and removed not only deployment of mods, but removed my selected versions so after the Steam updater was finished i had to reinstall everything and select desired versions again, which could be avoided if i had an option to do nothing.

title: [Collections] - add ability to fully sync the current active workshop collection with the currently active profile

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
We have two options here, which perhaps should be two different buttons for the curator to use.

1. Have the sync functionality completely remove all mods in the current active workshop collection, and re-add the mods which are active in the current profile; basically giving the curator a "fresh start" for that collection.
2. Have the sync functionality remove mods that are missing or disabled in the current profile, and add any new ones, maintaining metadata for the mods that are currently active.

title: Vortex Highlighting feature, maybe Select All Features

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
I was told to come here to present new ideas and improvements so I am. I have 1200+ mods so I am a big time Vortex user/fan. 

Why can't you search mods by Highlight on the Mods page and why can't you "Group the Table" by Highlights. With someone who has many many mods, I feel as if the Highlighting feature needs to be expanded upon such Highlighting the entire mod bar by the highlight color through like a setting or something. 
I find the Highlighting feature very useful for separating mod types and managing mods, but this feature is greatly underdeveloped and almost seems forgotten. There are also some highlight symbols I feel like should be included such as Trees 🌲 (tree mods), Water 🌊 (water mods), Clouds ☁️or☀️ (for sky related mods), Storm Cloud 🌩️ (Weather related mods), and maybe some type of small weapon for weapon mods 🔪,  maybe an Apple 🍎 for food related mods, a toy gun 🔫 or bow🏹 or some sort of magic rune for whatever weapon mods you are using. Then maybe something like metal cogs ⚙️ or mods that fix things. There is already a tools highlight though. 

Anyways this feature just needs more improvements.🍎🏹🔫⚙️

For select all features, I feel like you should be able to mass select all and have the option to either remove mod or uninstall mod. There is currently only a select all option for Remove when selecting multiple mods but no option to just uninstall them and keep them for later. 
This is something smaller, but it should just exist, and I have no idea why it doesn't when there is already a way to uninstall singular mods under the status column when you click the down arrow next to Enable🔽. You can't do this with multiple selected mods though, but you can enable and disable multiple mods at once. It's almost like this feature was left out of the selection tool bar for some reason.

title: Unexpected behaviour from FOMOD installer flag values

labels.name: waiting for reply
labels.description: Highlights that the development team is currently waiting for a response on the labeled issue

body:
### **Describe the Bug:**
When using a FOMOD installer, modifying the value of a previously set flag can result in unexpected behaviour:
- If a flag is set to "On" and a step after it has an option that modifies its value, the flag can be set to "Off" even if the selected option does not affect the flag.
- If an option changes the value of a flag used in a condition to determine the visibility of a previous step, that step may be erroneously be hidden or displayed when using the button to move back a step.

### **To Reproduce:**
See attached file for a FOMOD installer that demonstrates this issue.
The installer has four steps:
  - Step 1 sets the 'Test' flag to 'On.'
  - Step 2 requires 'Test' == 'On' for it to be displayed.
  - Step 3 has options to change the value of the 'Test' flag, showing the different results.
  - Step 4 requires 'Test' == 'On' for it to be displayed.

1. Use Vortex to install the demo FOMOD. Moving through the steps, you should see step 1, 2, and 3 displayed.
2. Step 3 has three options:

      A. Set 'Test' flag to 'Off'
      B. Don't Change Flag State
      C. Set 'Test' to 'On'

3. If Option A is chosen, the back button (bottom left) will change to lead back to Step 1, and the forward button (bottom right) will finish the install, correctly skipping Step 4.
4. Click the back button to return to Step 1. The forward button will now lead to Step 3 instead of Step 2.
5. Move back to Step 3 and select Option B instead. Despite not setting or changing any flags, the back button will lead to Step 1, and the forward button will still finish the install instead of displaying Step 4 (Note: This remains true even if you restart the install and skip selecting Option A, or select Option C and then change to Option B).
6. Change the selection in Step 3 to Option C. Step 2 and 4 will be displayed as expected.

### **Expected Behavior:**
- The back button should always lead to the step the user saw previously. Steps the user has seen should not be hidden when moving backward if the value of the flag controlling their visibility changes. If a step was not displayed when going forward through the install the first time, changing the value of the flag controlling its visibility should not let it become visible when moving backward.
- If a selected option makes no changes to a previously set flag, the value of that flag should not change.
- If a step has options that do make changes to the value of a previously set flag, those changes should be reverted when moving in reverse.

### **Platform:**
 - OS: Windows 10 Home, Version 22H2, OS Build 19045.4651, x64
 - Vortex Version: 1.11.7

### **Additional Context:**
From my testing, it appears that if a step has _any_ option that modifies the value of a previously set flag, then selecting options that do not change that flag will result in it being set to "Off" (even if they set a different flag). 
For example, if Option A is omitted from Step 3 in the demo file, selecting Option B will still result in 'Test' being set to 'Off' in Step 3. If both Option A and Option C are omitted, then Option B will have no effect on the 'Test' flag and behave as expected.

The order of the options in Step 3 does not appear to have any affect on the incorrect flag values. If Option C is put first in the list, Option B will still set the 'Test' flag to 'Off.' Changing the names of the options so they have a different alphabetical order also has no effect.

Please let me know if I can provide any more information, or if anything is unclear. If you'd like assistance with testing possible fixes I'm happy to help with that as well!

[FOMOD-Flag-Value-Bug-Demo.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16508000/FOMOD-Flag-Value-Bug-Demo.zip)

title: Node events memory leak fixes
body:
The rest of the leaks are within the collections extension; still trying to figure out how to deal with that without rocking the boat too much.

The functionality for the main app is still solid though.

- Ensures that the symlink activator is no longer "stuck" behind the elevation notification.
- Better error handling throughout the application, React errors will no longer block the entire page view when something fails to render, it will block the specific component that failed to render (which can indeed be a whole page in some cases)
- Dynamic divs are now wrapped in an ErrorBoundary and will provide a way for users to report any rendering issues that occur.
- General improvements to the DOM's consistency (removed anti-patterns) - this might screw up the stylesheets a bit (specifically for ECD)
- Ensured that we add and remove listeners correctly in the QuickLauncher and MainWindow components.


Please ignore until 1.13.x is worked on

title: Electron's relaunch function doesn't call the base nodeEmitter when restarting Vortex
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A Vortex instance that has been started with `--user-data` forgets it when restarting after actions requiring Vortex to restart.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The restarted instance should remember the provided `--user-data`

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
At present when I can, I just close the instance instead of restarting. This currently only doesn't work when restoring state backups.

**Additional context**
I realise that the use of the `--user-data` parameter is an unsupported and advanced usage of Vortex, but it would be handy if Vortex would remember being told a different `{userdata}` location whenever that instance needs to restart.

title: Add API for game specific fallback purge mechanism when unmanaging a game/purging different instance

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
Currently Vortex will use the deployment manifest when trying to ascertain which files need to be removed. This is insufficient depending on the game extension which may be applying patches or overwriting game files on `did-purge` and results in orphaned/missing files in the game directory.

We should improve the fallback mechanism to at the very least try to call the purge events defined by the game extension if possible (game extension may have been removed and now re-installed, etc)

The deployment manifest should also be enhanced to contain the version of the game extension so that the fallback purge can ascertain whether it's even possible to call the purge events (different game extension versions may have different purge mechanisms)

title: Vortex fails to unpack bin folders and DLLs using "Install" option
body:
**Describe the bug**
I recently started using Vortex again with Bannerlord. I'm having a problem with DLL unpacking. When a mod is *installed*, the `bin` folder and `dll` files go missing.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Grab a mod like https://www.nexusmods.com/mountandblade2bannerlord/mods/592
2. Add it to Vortex
3. Install it
4. Look at the staging mods area's folders

**Expected behavior**
The `bin` folder and `dll` files should exist.

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Win11
 - Vortex Version 1.11.6

**Additional context**
Using the "Unpack (as-is)" option _does_ end up creating the `bin` folder. But it also does a pure unpack directly into the staging folder, which then causes problem with folder/file hierarchy when you go to actually enable/install the mods.

title: [Mod Dependency Manager] - Add UI elements to highlight a modType conflict

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
Currently we do not highlight any file conflicts that occur between mods of different modTypes. This can lead to confusion as the user isn't aware of which mods are causing the purge on deployment event when resolving modType conflicts.

We should:
- Add a visible marker in the override editor to highlight that the override they're setting will trigger the modType conflict resolution functionality.
- Add a UI element that allows the user to delete the overriden files that are part of that modType conflict so that they're able to avoid the purge.
- Add a visible marker on the mods page so that users can tell when a mod entry is currently causing a modType conflict.
- Small redesign on mod rules, file override dialogs to better explain what is happening.
- If/when a "global" mod rule is changed, ask the user if he wishes to remove the file overrides involved in that conflict.

title: [Collections] - installer options of mods with changed fomod structures not published correctly
[Collections] - Parallel download/install of mods should be optional

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
Currently Vortex will download and install mods in parallel - due to technical restrictions (NodeJS being single threaded) running both in parallel will needlessly slow down the application as both download and install managers are fighting over the thread.

We can speed up the collection download/installation by giving the user the option to install the mods only after the collection is fully downloaded. This should be configurable through the settings page AND via a checkbox when the collection install dialog is displayed.

title: Plugin group is not set acccording to collection config if plugin is already assigned a different group.

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Describe the bug**
When you install collection that sets plugin to certain group you would expect it to add this plugin to this group. And it happens but only if it isn't already assigned to any group. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install collection that sets plugin to certain group 
2. Uninstall this collection
3. Install other collection that uses same plugin but with different group assingment.

**Expected behavior**
Plugin is set to group specified in collection config.


**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Vortex Version 1.10.8

**Additional context**
Example collections:
[Gate to Sovngard](https://next.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/collections/qdurkx) 
Sets fwmf for fantasy paper maps.esp as custom group "late"
[Constellations - A true RPG](https://next.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/collections/9zfscf) 
After installation you are met with cyclic interaction between plugins becasue fwmf for fantasy paper maps.esp is still "late" instead of "paper maps" as defined in Constellations collection.json


Same behaviour (collection group assingment not being applied) can be observed if you manually set a plugin to different group allowing for easier testing of this issue (instead of requiring to download two collections, you can download just one, then change assingment and reinstall this collection)


If i manually remove assingmet to a group from a plugin and reinstall collection it gets assigned properly.

title: Investigate redirecting users to other mod managers where NXM links are enabled but Vortex doesn't support it

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When there is an alternative mod manager using `NXM://` links we can only show "Vortex" buttons on the website which can be confusing/misleading for users. However, we don't want to stop third-party tools from taking advantage of our site to make modding easier for their communities. 

As changing this on the website side is very complex, it may be better in the short term to have these games show up in Vortex but direct the users to install the alternative tool when they try to manage it. 

We may also want to consider intercepting downloads for these games with a warning before the user starts the process. 

Games that this applies to (so far):
- Mass Effect 1
- Mass Effect 2
- Mass Effect 3
- Mass Effect Legendary Edition
- Escape The Backrooms

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Show the game tile in Vortex but when the user clicks on it, show a message pointing them to the alternative mod manager. We should also recommend NXM Proxy to allow downloads for specific games to be routed out of Vortex: https://www.nexusmods.com/site/mods/288

Example concept 
[unsupported-games.zip](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/files/15175620/unsupported-games.zip)



**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Changing the website. 

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

title: Vortex seems to adding an "Account Unknown" to each modfile's File Permissions
body:
**Describe the bug**
Each time I install a new mod, when I go visit the mod's files (whether in the staging folder or the game/data folder) my Explorer PreviewHandlers are not allowed to read the contents of these files. This indicates a problem with File Permissions. This is due to a UAC permission being added to each file. When viewing the UAC settings, there will be an "Account Unknown". It displays an account GUID (or whatever that ID is called) which does not exist anywhere in my Windows Registry, which means it's an account from somebody else's machine (a developer's machine?).


**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Download a mod, preferably something that has a text file which could be read by an Explorer PreviewHandler.
2. Navigate to the mod's staging folder. (have Explorer's Preview Panel open), is it blocked?  [first screenshot]
3. Right-click the modfile, choose Properties, then choose the 'Security' tab. Can you see "Account Unknown(S-1-15-2-9715996181819307607-1109918363-and-so-on)?  [second screenshot]
4. Click the 'Advanced' button, if the unknown account is there, notice that it's not being inherited from the Parent Object (despite it saying that it does inherit). So because of this oddity, we will have to press 'Disable inheritance', then click "Remove all inherited permissions from this object", click 'Apply', click 'Enable inheritance', and then click 'Apply'. The Unknown account should not re-appear. Now click 'Okay' twice. The file can now be viewed by Explorer PreviewHandler (IE permission problem solved).
*Note: of course if it happens to be that this permission came from YOUR machine, then you might not see "Account Unknown" but your actual account might show up there. LOL!

**Expected behavior**
The expected behavior is that this doesn't happen at all. I suspect that somehow modfiles are inheriting permissions from a developer's machine, but what do I know? But hey, another interesting thing that I've noticed is that after I apply my fix, if I reinstall the mod with Vortex the problem comes right back and it's the same "Account Unknown(S-1-15-bla-bla-bla)" which doesn't exist on my machine. Where is it coming from?



**Screenshots**

![Screenshot 2024-04-26 235810](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/29521840/dc5097ae-ae88-4e45-9040-150c4bf4f3c6)

title: error: Valheim "BepInEx" could not run preloader

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:

body:
**The bug**
Whenever the currently managed mods are deployed, vortex rewrites the configuration on "doorstop_config.ini" file and sets "dllSearchPathOverride" value as "unstripped_corlib", which causes a preloader error. This problem occurs because the Vortex Mod Manager forcefully manages BepInEx (even if this is disabled on the mods list), and even if we want to install it manually, it keeps rewriting the same files and causing this problem after every deployment.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to the mods list of the game;
2. Disable "denikson-BepInExPack_Valheim-...";
3. Enable any mod;
4. Let the auto-deploy happen;
5. Launch the game;

**Expected behavior**
It should not manage the BepInEx extension if it is disabled by the user.

**Screenshots**
Preloader error:
![BepInEx Log Error](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/74029117/6e08f55d-411e-48ee-9251-178265e45a1d)

title: Collection downloads stop when minimized or out of viewport
body:
**Description**
When you are downloading a mod collection the downloads pause whenever vortex gets mnimized or another fullscreen application is used on the same screen making vortex leave the viewport.

**To Reproduce**
1. Start the download of a mod collection.
2. View your downloads graph and remember the current point
3. Minimize vortex or open another application ontop of it hiding vortex
4. Wait a few minutes

When you return you will see that the downloads graph will not have moved since the last time it was in view.

**Expected behavior**
I expect the downloads to continue even when vortex is out of view or minimized

**Screenshot**
![Vortex-downloads](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/93537121/5cd47b30-890c-46b8-9ad1-31afa7daea7d)
In the image above several points are numbered below I'll inform what happend on each and when.

1. Time: 12:07, Action: Another application got opened as fullscreen ontop of the screen where vortex is located.
2. Time: 12:33, Action: The fullscreen application gets closed and vortex downloads continue as it is now back in view.
3. Time: 12:40, Action: Minimize vortex.
4. Time 12:46, Action: Unminimize vortex.
5. Time 12:47, Action: Minimize vortex.
6. Time 13:12, Action Unmimimize vortex. (After 6 the downloads continue)

**Platform:**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Vortex Version: 1.10.8

title: Installer reports that 'Vortex can't be closed' instead of 'No space left on device'
body:
**Describe the bug**
Vortex installer reports that Vortex can't be closed, even if Vortex does not run at all
The problem was that I had no space left on the device where Vortex was being installed

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install Vortex to c:\any_folder
2. Have no space left on c:\

**Expected behavior**
Vortex installer reports that there is no space left on the device

**Screenshots**
![image](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/12056222/b1459f8f-792a-441e-bad1-5998c15377ed)

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version Vortex-1-1-10-8-1710319525 and Vortex-1-1-6-14-1665055915

body:
Bumps [tar](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar) from 6.1.12 to 6.2.1.
Release notes

Sourced from tar's releases.

v6.1.13

6.1.13 (2022-12-07)

Dependencies

  • cc4e0dd #343 bump minipass from 3.3.6 to 4.0.0
Changelog

Sourced from tar's changelog.

Changelog

7.0

  • Rewrite in TypeScript, provide ESM and CommonJS hybrid interface
  • Add tree-shake friendly exports, like import('tar/create') and import('tar/read-entry') to get individual functions or classes.
  • Add chmod option that defaults to false, and deprecate noChmod. That is, reverse the default option regarding explicitly setting file system modes to match tar entry settings.
  • Add processUmask option to avoid having to call process.umask() when chmod: true (or noChmod: false) is set.

6.2

  • Add support for brotli compression
  • Add maxDepth option to prevent extraction into excessively deep folders.

6.1

  • remove dead link to benchmarks (#313) (@​yetzt)
  • add examples/explanation of using tar.t (@​isaacs)
  • ensure close event is emited after stream has ended (@​webark)
  • replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (@​CommanderRoot, @​lukekarrys)

6.0

  • Drop support for node 6 and 8
  • fix symlinks and hardlinks on windows being packed with \-style path targets

5.0

  • Address unpack race conditions using path reservations
  • Change large-numbers errors from TypeError to Error
  • Add TAR_* error codes
  • Raise TAR_BAD_ARCHIVE warning/error when there are no valid entries found in an archive
  • do not treat ignored entries as an invalid archive
  • drop support for node v4
  • unpack: conditionally use a file mapping to write files on Windows
  • Set more portable 'mode' value in portable mode
  • Set portable gzip option in portable mode

... (truncated)

Commits
  • bef7b1e 6.2.1
  • fe8cd57 prevent extraction in excessively deep subfolders
  • fe7ebfd remove security.md
  • 5bc9d40 6.2.0

  • e483220 get rid of npm lint stuff
  • 689928a ci that works outside of npm org
  • db6f539 file inference improvements for .tbr and .tgz
  • 336fa8f refactor: dry and other pr comments
  • eeba222 chore: lint fixes
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

title: Overhaul External Changes dialog

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
Re-design external changes so it's visually better, makes more sense to the end user but with minimal dev time. Functionality wise it's going to be the same.

The below is a design that keeps our data model the same but provides a better UX

Early app design to deal with external changes

![Image](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/26166085/85fdbcb6-7be7-45ab-8fd1-8e04f0d0d500)

Vortex version mixing what we have now and what is above

![Image](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/26166085/eca31c9c-7072-452f-b099-d5b5c02418b7)

### Previous issue

The External Changes Dialog (ECD) is a very useful tool for users to apply/revert changes made to their modding environment. Unfortunately it's information heavy (as it should be) and may confuse or even scare the users into applying changes such as the removal of affected mod files from the game's staging folder.

Currently ECD will default to the removal or application of a mod file change, and it's very easy to mis-click and ruin your modding environment.

#### Impact

I would suggest we default to "revert" instead, which should ensure that any removal or modification of mod files is not accidental.

Additionally, similar to the new-files event handler, we should add a new event intercept-external-changes which allows extensions to intercept expected file changes which could realistically be handled automatically by the extension itself (e.g. mod configuration changes committed inside a game)

title: [StardewValley] Updating any mod wipes the mod's config
body:
**Describe the bug**
When ever you update a mod in Stardew Valley via Vortex, it will delete the config.json file that is within the mod's folder.
Which means you have to reset the config options every time you install an update.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. See a mod that needs updating
2. Update the mod
3. Now the config file is gone


**Expected behavior**
It should not be deleting the config files unless the updated mod specifically has a replacement file.

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version 1.10.8

**Additional context and info**
I would not think it'd be related but just on the off chance it comes up, Deployment Method is set to Move.

The wiping of config files have happened so much that I ended up with a powershell script that I run prior to doing updates that just backups every json file so that if I notice something changed I can just revert. But it's still quite annoying to have to do that.

If this is looked into to be fixed, the process can't also simply be setup to ignore config.json files, due to mods using sub directories to store additional farm/save file specific config files. Like the Happy Birthday mod stores it's per save info in the data folder with unique number IDs (the seed maybe? never looked into it) as the file name for the json file.

I would think idealy the method to go about it would be to see what files were in the pre-update archive to see which files have been procedurally generated (like the config files tend to be) and remove those before applying the update.

title: Choose game store if more than one game installation is found

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
When managing a game for the first time, Vortex searches for installs based on priority order when using `util.GameStoreHelper.findByAppId`. This then writes that information to state and very difficult to reset to work again.

I propose instead of when you click Manage and it uses only the single install that is found, we get a dialog showing all installs that have been found and you choose which one from radio buttons.

The user flow would be:

Go to go Games, click Manage
If a no install, you get the usual prompt to choose manually.
If a single install, you proceed to Manage that game.
If multiple installs found, you get a Dialog with 'Multiple installs found' and a description like 'Multiple installs of {GAMENAME} have been found, which one would you like to manage?' Followed by radio buttons of each install with game path and game store like:

- C:\GOG Games\Witcher 3 (GOG)
- C:\Games\Witcher 3 (Epic)
- D:\Steam\steamapps\common\Stardfew Valley (Steam)

Buttons at the bottom would be 'Cancel' and 'Manage' with Manage only enabled if something is selected above

This would be VERY useful for testing, as well as just be useful for users.

title: "Expand all" and "Collapse all" buttons unexpected behaviour
body:
**Describe the bug**
"Expand all" button expands all groups but the one it was called on, the group it was called on gets collapsed instead, the same with "Collapse all" button but the other way around - it collapses all groups but the one it was called on, the group it was called on gets expanded instead

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Group the list by any attribute
2. Expand all the groups
3. Collapse one group
4. Use "Collapse all" button on the group from step 3
5. All groups but the group from step 3 get collapsed, the group from step 3 gets expanded instead

OR

1. Group the list by any attribute
2. Collapse all the groups
3. Expand one group
4. Use "Expand all" button on the group from step 3
5. All groups but the group from step 3 get expanded, the group from step 3 gets collapsed instead

**Expected behavior**
All groups get expanded/collapsed, including the one it was called on

**Platform**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version: 1.9.12

title: Vortex Premium Collection Install is Bugged (Stalls), There's a Workaround That Shows it Can Improve
body:
When you're installing any collection with premium, on the install side of things, there are constant stalls. Doesn't matter the size of the collection.

As an example, on the test version of my team's collection, which is ~500 megabytes:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvsEh7MSsoc](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvsEh7MSsoc)

The install process with premium takes 17 minutes.

If you close Vortex and restart it every time it pauses on a mod this is what happens:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYi-gpdp7uA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYi-gpdp7uA)

The install process takes ~6 minutes. This is a considerable difference and makes me think there's an issue on the Vortex side of things that could improve.

Here's the same with the closing and opening parts cut out for real install time in Vortex:

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MLxhamEJu3E](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MLxhamEJu3E)

Approximately 4 minutes.

We're talking about 4 times less time to finish. Is this done purposefully or an issue in Vortex, and if it is an issue... can it be fixed? It seems to be a delay on the install side of things rather than downloading.

(Just as a fun comparison, it takes 30 seconds to download with premium on wabbajack: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5OQW5kSjXQ](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5OQW5kSjXQ)

title: Please add Proxy Settings
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In internet restricted areas, we use proxies to bypass restriction. But most proxies are slow and inefficient, so we enable proxy only for restricted website (using browser extensions like [_SwitchyOmega_](https://github.com/FelisCatus/SwitchyOmega)) or software (_Telegram_, _Pikpak_, _Mega_, etc) . They all has separate proxy settings, which works nicely in our situation.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Adding separate SOCKS or HTTP proxy setting in Vortex.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Using [_Proxifier_](https://www.proxifier.com/) is a solution, but it's a paid software and can be hard to setup.

title: Deployment interrupted - Addins file is invalid (Dragon Age: Origins)
body:
**Bug Description:**
When asked to Elevate and Deploy mods for Dragon Age: Origins (DAO), deployment always fails due to an invalid AddIns.xml file located at C:\Users\<MyUserName>\AppData\Roaming\Vortex\dragonage\mods\__merged.dazip\Settings\AddIns.xml. If you navigate to this location, open AddIns.xml in a text editor (e.g., Notepad++), then it appears that the file is essentially empty (i.e. no mods are included).

**AddIns.xml Contents:**
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<!--   AddIn information -->
<AddInsList />

```
**Steps To Reproduce:**
1. Login to Steam and (uninstall/re)install DAO
2. Install Vortex Mod Manager, go to the Games tab, scroll through the list to find DAO, and then click the Manage button for DAO.
![Vortex - DAO Managed Game](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/152127448/249d0d9e-bbf3-4a8e-b796-99950dc16a8e)
3. Login to my [nexusmods.com](https://www.nexusmods.com/) account, navigate to an arbitrary DAO mod that has a "Mod Manager Download" option rather than the "Manual Download" option (e.g., [Morrigan Restoration Patch](https://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/1120?tab=files)), and then click on the "Mod Manager Download" button to wait for the download to complete in Vortex.
![Morrigan Restoration Patch - Mod Manager Download](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/152127448/5bc17d14-8f30-409e-911f-b39889e453a3)
4. Either wait on the Downloads tab or go to the Mods tab in Vortex to enable the downloaded mod, and then when notified about the need to elevate and deploy, click the Elevate button in the notification.
![Morrigan Restoration Patch - Vortex Download + Elevate + Deploy](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/152127448/28cda6b2-f939-413a-86d1-1a42e31c6f4d)
5. After completing these steps, I always get the same error message:
**Deployment interrupted**
Addins file is invalid - "C:\Users\<MyUserName>\AppData\Roaming\Vortex\dragonage\mods\__merged.dazip\Settings\AddIns.xml"

**Expected Behavior:**
For mods to successfully deploy, which was not a problem in the past (pre-2023) using either the Nexus Mod Manager or the Vortex Mod Manager.

**Screenshots:**
Error message pop-up
![Vortex - Deployment Interrupted + Deployment Necessary](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/152127448/1171d06b-547c-4370-9c7a-334846e8b050)

**Platform:**
 - OS: Windows 10 Home (Version 22H2, OS Build 19045.3693, Windows Feature Experience Pack 1000.19053.1000.0) --> formerly Windows 7 before updating in mid 2023
 - RAM: 8 GB
 - CPU: Intel Core i7-3610QM CPU @ 2.30 GHz (Driver Version 10.0.19041.3636)
 - GPU: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660M (2 GB VRAM, Driver Version 23.2.13.8857)
 - Vortex Version: Vortex 1.9.7 (Electron 25.8.4, Node 18.15.0, Chrome 114.0.5735.289)
 - DAO Install Location: E:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Dragon Age Ultimate Edition

**Additional Context:**
The reason I got in this mess in the first place was that after updating from Windows 7 to 10, I ran into an issue where my save games would not load properly (i.e. they would load indefinitely). I thought perhaps something got corrupted during the Windows update, so I made a backup of the C:\Users\<MyUserName>\Documents\BioWare\Dragon Age directory, uninstalled all of my mods via Vortex, then uninstalled Vortex, and finally uninstalled DAO itself. After doing this, I also did my best to purge all traces of Vortex on my machine by deleting all files in the following locations:
- C:\Program Files\Black Tree Gaming Ltd\Vortex
- C:\Users\CrocodileMundi\AppData\Local\Black_Tree_Gaming
- C:\Users\CrocodileMundi\AppData\Local\vortex-updater
- C:\Users\<MyUserName>\AppData\Roaming\Vortex

I also looked through my Windows registry entries to see if I could find any lingering Black Tree Gaming or Vortex-related items, but couldn't, so at that point I figured I'd gotten rid of it entirely.

After going through these steps, I worked through the "Steps to Reproduce" listed above as a bare bones test and still kept running into the same issue. No amount of clean installs of DAO and Vortex seem to help, so hopefully you see something here that I missed, or else find a bug that needs addressing.

Thanks!

title: Vortex will only install mods if it is not obscured by other windows and is at least partially visible.
body:
**Describe the bug**
Vortex only does stuff when you can see it. Like actually see it visually. After ~30 seconds it stops installing (maybe downloading too, I haven't tested) if the window is not visible.

I'm not even talking about minimising the program, it's enough to put another, non-fullscreen window on top of it to hide it completely.

I've never seen a program behave like this, as far as I know programs can't even tell if they're visible when another non-fullscreen window is on top of them, but it seems Vortex can.

**To Reproduce**

1. open Vortex and start some installation
2. open Task Manager and look at Vortex CPU usage
3. cover Vortex with another window or minimise it
4. wait ~30 sec
5. don't move your mouse over Vortex window, it will cause CPU usage from windows updating the window, not from downloading/installing (normal windows behaviour)
6. watch CPU usage drop to 0% and stay there

**Expected behavior**
continue to install mods when not visible

**Screenshots**
Hard to show with just a screenshot but this is my NAS's traffic. Vortex was active all the time, but as you can see nothing happend for hours when I was using the PC and Vortex was hidden behind discord. Discrod was not opened in fullscreen.

And here is one where I moved the Paint window above Vortex, notice the CPU and drive usage of Vortex. It takes roughly 30 seconds to drop to 0% and it will stay there until at least a bit of the Vortex window is visible again.
![image](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/49845653/3dc1528a-79d2-487b-b8ec-2fce897f7096)

title: Provide a .NET self-contained version
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Given the amount of programs that use .NET, it's usually to have systems with a lot of old redistributables installed. Now that .NET is fully permissive, it can be shipped with the programs themselves. Given Vortex has a hard requirement for a pinned .NET version, I think it makes sense to keep it independent from the system one

**Describe the solution you'd like**
- That Vortex is published [self-contained](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/#publish-self-contained) by default (preferred, since it's simpler for all users and space is cheap nowadays).
- That an additional "full" version (or similar nomenclature) is released with .NET builtin.

title: Triaged [Review] - Feature Request: Import Spriggit projects as mods into Vortex/NMA
body:
[Spriggit](https://github.com/Mutagen-Modding/Spriggit) is a tool used to convert ESPs to/from YAML/JSON files. This lets mod authors manage and version control their mods much more easily.

Allow users to drag-and-drop a zip file containing a Spriggit project (YAMLs, etc.) into Vortex/NMA. The plugin will invoke Spriggit to pre-process these files, and convert them into one or more ESPs under the hood.

These generated ESPs can then be sent to the Vortex Staging folder as usual. The deployment process will remain the same.

title: Suggestion - Purge Rules Function
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I manage several collections, and users are continuously reporting errors with mod rules and cycles because of rules that were already present in their Vortex installation and persist across profiles. Also, I am unable to manage more than two collections for the same game on the same computer, since Vortex only has the possibility of two instances (shared and per user modes).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A function that allows the purging of rules from a Vortex instance so that this can be addressed by users without switching instances or reinstalling Vortex.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Having the possibility of unlimited instances without changing user modes would also address this issue.

**Additional context**
This has been by far the biggest technical issue that users have with my collections, and is going to be a serious problem for me soon as I release additional collections.

title: Error 403 when downloading mods
body:
**Describe the bug**



**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Be logged in as non-premium user.
2. Go to a mod page. Tested with [SkyUI](https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/12604?tab=files).
3. Click on "Mod Manager Download"
4. Choose "Slow Download"
5. Vortex opens to download the mod
6. Request fails immediately with HTTP status code 403 and this body:
   ```json
   {
      "code":403,
      "message":"You don't have permission to get download links from the API without visting nexusmods.com -\nthis is for premium users only."
   }
   ```
   (I did not get this message from Vortex, but rather by triggering the request via the browser so that I can get a proper response)     
  This is caused by requesting this URL: https://api.nexusmods.com/v1/games/skyrimspecialedition/mods/12604/files/35407/download_link

I traced this bug down as much as I could already by launching Vortex with the `--inspector` flag. But all I could find is that `nexus.getDownloadURLs` should be properly called. I also inspected the headers, and a (presumably) valid HTTP `Authentication` header with a `Bearer <jwt>` is set. 

What I found a bit suspicious is that `premiumUserDownload` is called instead of `freeUserDownload`, but I assume this is correct, because there is a key present in the `nxm:` URL.

**Expected behavior**
Non-premium users should be able to download mods via the free tier.

**Screenshots**
UI Error:
![image](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/assets/18900196/7d36cf07-bb56-40e7-8828-80ab7efc2352)


**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux, Steam Deck
 - Vortex Version: 1.8.5, also tested with beta version 1.9.3

**Additional context**
I know you don't support Linux, but I hope you don't just discard the issue.

I'll gladly debug the issue as well as I can, though my response time might be limited. Any guidance on where I can set breakpoints would be greatly appreciated.

title: Feature Request: Attach notes to uninstalled mods
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
There's a section where you can write notes on a mod. When I'm building a mod list, sometimes I install and uninstall mods several times as I try out different combinations. But if I write myself a note, like "Delete the scripts folder if installed with X mod," and then I uninstall the mod, the note is gone.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like the notes to stay attached to the mod even when uninstalled, and be able to write notes on mods that aren't installed yet just like I can edit the other metadata.

title: Mod Compatibility Troubleshooting Wizard

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Mods in games are amazing and often, I find myself installing a lot of mods for a game. This is great when it works, but troubleshooting compatibility issues between mods can often be a pain. When you have over 100 mods installed for a game, trying to find out which one is causing an issue can take quite some time.

Sometimes there's an error, and it's as simple as reading the message. However, sometimes its more frustrating issues like weird in-world interactions, broken dialogue, etc. and you have to go through the process of removing mods to see which one causes the problem.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A simple mod compatibility troubleshooting tool that assists in the process of enabling/disabling mods to isolate the cause of a problem when troubleshooting.

It would start by asking which mod you are having a problem with. First, it disables all mods except this one (and its dependencies) and runs the game. When the game closes, it asks if you are still encountering the issue. If so, it tells you to report your problem to the mod author. If not, it re-enables all your mods, then starts the process of removing them (except the one the user provided) to see which two mods are having issues interacting.

I believe the most efficient way to do this is with an approach similar to that of a binary search. The process looks something like this:

1. Disable half the mods that are enabled (making sure to look at dependencies).
2. Run the game. When the game closes, ask if the user is still having their issue. If they are, go back to step 1.
3. If the user is no longer having the issue, disable all mods except the one the user provided and the mods that were removed in step 1. Now, go back to step 1.

Once this process has isolated the problem down to just the mod the user provided and one other mod (plus any dependencies for either of them), tell the user to report the issue to both mod authors, as the problem likely comes from one of them.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative to this process that is currently available is just doing everything I said manually. That's totally possible, but I think having this automated utility would speed up the process a lot, and could save a lot of developers the trouble of back and forth arguments over who's mod is causing a compatibility issue, and save users the trouble of waiting forever on a mod developer to respond to a bug report, only to find out the problem is caused by another mod and should be reported to its author instead.

**Additional context**

title: [Request/ModManagement] Allow for an optional separate user-friendly version attribute for display purposes only

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In some mod ecosystems (Elder Scrolls Online specifically) the mod version that a user sees is different from the version of the mod itself. One very prominent example is LibAddonMenu, an addon that's an incredibly popular requirement:

```json
{
    "id": 7,
    "categoryId": 53,
    "version": "2.0 r34",
    "lastUpdate": 1654515351000,
    "title": "LibAddonMenu",
    "author": "sirinsidiator",
    "fileInfoUri": "https://www.esoui.com/downloads/info7-LibAddonMenu.html",
    "checksum": "8ea9145e40b02c4d57b8b0cec3315b11",
    "addons": [
        {
            "path": "LibAddonMenu-2.0",
            "addOnVersion": "34",
            "apiVersion": "101033 101034",
            "library": true,
        }
    ],
    "library": true
}
```

This is an example where the user-friendly version is something that's not compatible with semver, but there are examples where the `addOnVersion` is very distinct from the `version`. A good example of that is HarvestMap, a rather popular addon in the community:

```json
{
  "id": 57,
  "categoryId": 24,
  "version": "3.15.12",
  "lastUpdate": 1658687737000,
  "title": "HarvestMap",
  "author": "Shinni",
  "fileInfoUri": "https://www.esoui.com/downloads/info57-HarvestMap.html",
  "checksum": "b56de17d1ab942ac7ee1d2b35425c998",
  "addons": [
    {
      "path": "HarvestMap",
      "addOnVersion": "314999",
      "apiVersion": "101034 101033"
    }
  ]
}
```

Here you can see that the addOnVersion is very different from the user displayed version. When the mods state their dependencies, they do so using the `addOnVersion`, so a mod requiring HarvestMap version `3.15.12` or up would state its dependency as `HarvestMap>=314999`.

The issue arises that if I put the addOnVersion in the `version` attribute of the mod in Vortex then it creates confusion with the user as to what version of the addon they have, since that's not what version the mod refers to. However, if I put the user-friendly version in the `version` attribute now I can no longer use `matchVersion` in `IReference` for mod rules, since the user-friendly versions have no constraints on being semver coercible or not.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like a secondary, optional, attribute for storing a user-friendly version attribute, something like `displayVersion` (though perhaps with a different name, since that sounds like a boolean you'd pass in to hide the version number) that would then be used in [ModList::calcVersion](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/blob/838a073fa0a326eb4877ca721b0c9cf3b69d61e0/src/extensions/mod_management/views/ModList.tsx#L529) (and other appropriate places) as a null coalesce with the existing version attribute, to allow for a display override.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've considered just putting the addOnVersion in the `version` attribute, but decided against it for the reason of user confusion as listed above. The alternative I ended up using was to not use `matchVersion` at all but instead to perform the version check when installing a mod since I'm automatically installing it's dependencies along with it.

This raises a different issue however, as it means that when updating a dependency, the mod that depends on it will still match the old version of the dependency when checking for references even though it's disabled ([In testRef if the version isn't fuzzy](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/blob/1e25b01b4d66c851b7eb424c69131af7024f71c6/src/extensions/mod_management/util/testModReference.ts#L154)), leading to instances where Vortex thinks there's an unfilled dependency even though it's filled with a newer version of the mod.

**Additional context**
The context here is that I'm building/maintaining an extension that adds Vortex support for ESOUI, the most popular site for ESO mods, and as stated above their user-displayed versions are not always semver coercible.

title: If a redundant mod is removed, if the mod that caused the redundancy is removed, then the original redundant mod should be reinstated

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In cases where a mod may have optional parts presented as separate downloads, it is possible for those optional parts to be superseded by another mod from another author.  This will result in a redundant mod message, and the redundant mod may be removed to clear the message and resolve the situation.  If the mod from the other author is subsequently removed, it no longer makes the first mod redundant, but there is nothing to remind the user to enable the mod that was removed because it was redundant.  Sometimes, based on how things are named, it is not obvious by the line in the mods list that this mod needs to be enabled and it may be missed.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I am looking for user assistance help by Vortex. I would like some way for Vortex to track redundant mods so that if a mod that caused a redundancy is removed, there is something to remind the user that there is a formerly redundant mod that was disabled. 

One possible suggestion is to change the color of the lightning bolt to indicate that the mod is redundant, not just conflicting. My fear is that if the mod causing the redundancy is removed, this information could be lost.

The suggestion I would like to see is the above, plus a message that pops up when the mod creating the redundancy is removed or disabled to inform that the original mod is no longer redundant.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
One alternative is to leave the redundant mod active so that it is always loaded, then superseded during deployment.  It harms nothing to leave it that way, but it does generate a new redundant message in each case, even if the user's decision has already been made to ignore the message.

Another alternative is to write a note in the main mod that mentions that an optional file was removed from the mod, and which mod replaced that file.  This is a little more work, and is not foolproof since the user may forget to check.  I find it more useful to add this to the main mod than to the one that was redundant.  The main problem with this is knowing to look at the notes.  There is no icon to indicate that there are user notes for a mod.

**Additional context**
N/A

title: Uninstall is broken, doesn't clean config (registry), resulting in endless startup errors when reinstalling

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**The Bug**
Somewhere along the way Vortex found the Zenimax launcher on my "F:\" drive.  That drive is no longer on the system, but the letter is used by a DVD drive now.  There appears to be no way whatsoever to actually remove this path from Vortex, so much so that even a full Uninstall doesn't remove this setting causing the attached exception every single time Vortex starts.

So really, there are multiple issues here, but this issue is in relation to "Uninstall" being incomplete.  This is a bigger issue because often one of the best workarounds for dealing with software bugs that screw up their configuration is to Uninstall/Reinstall that software to reset the corrupted configuration.  That workaround is not possible here.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install the Zenimax Launcher.
2. Tell Vortex to go find new games, including whatever you installed that launcher for (DragonAge: Origins, etc)
3. Uninstall the Zenimax Launcher and move the drive letter it was on to a non-harddrive (DVD, CD, etc)
4. Launch Vortex and watch it choke

**Expected behavior**
Vortex should simply see that the path no longer exists (including if the device letter no longer represents a hard drive) and simply remove the path from its config, effectively it "lost" the game like any other game that got uninstalled.

**Screenshots**

However, currently, the checkboxes are not greyed out and are thus presented identically to selected options. * "Required" options that are presented as radio buttons are not greyed out, either. Furthermore, it would seem that the last option in the list that has a pre-selection type (i.e. "Required" or "Recommended") gets the default selection. # **To Reproduce** 1. title: Suggestion: Hyperlink hovertext and right-click -> copy mod URL

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
# Summary
Opening hyperlinks from the Vortex client in the system's default browser is not always preferable. An obvious solution would be implementing a setting to define a "Vortex default browser" or "custom commandline syntax for opening URL". However, I interpret this request as "wontfix", per https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/issues/6063.

Short of that, a handy, and perhaps simpler feature would be to add a "copy mod URL to clipboard" context menu option and/or a "right-click -> copy mod URL" feature, for directly-displayed hyperlinks.

Alternatively, a mod/plugin's URL could be added to the mod's details side panel. There is already a hyperlink for the mod author here, so I feel like this is an appropriate place for a hyperlink to the mod itself as well, ideally with the above "right-click -> copy URL" feature implemented.

In general, the less clicks necessary to get a URL onto the clipboard and into the desired external application, the better.

As it is, the only way I can find to open a given mod's URL in a preferred, non-system-default application is to either A) open the link in the system-default browser and then manually copy the link and paste it elsewhere, or B) manually search for and navigate to it, without any help from Vortex.

In the same vein, it's fairly common for hovering the mouse over hyperlinked text to display some sort of indication as to the hyperlink's URL, either as a hovertext popup, or in a status bar. Granted, this is usually more of a security thing, which isn't as pressing in Vortex due to hyperlinks being commonly limited to URLs in the nexusmods domain. But it would still be an appreciated feature I think.

title: Potential issues between Bethesda Games on Xbox Game Pass and Profiles
body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been working on a load-order related extension in my free time and noticed a potential issue whereby Vortex may not manage the correct version of the plugins.txt and loadorder.txt files when the user has the Xbox version of the game. 

So, to start, I'm looking at the `context.registerProfileFile()` call as shown here:
https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/extension-plugin-management/blob/1c5dde7d269e787e662fffacd11bc64a8de6ab61/src/index.ts#L314

This works perfectly fine when called in this instance, however, there are a few cases where the AppData path will be different based on how the game is installed (Enderal/Xbox Game Pass). 

I have attempted to mitigate this here: https://github.com/Pickysaurus/vortex-hybrid-loadorder/blob/main/src/index.ts#L163

However, you cannot call `context.registerProfileFile()` this late in the setup without Vortex sending a warning to the log file (and, presumably, failing). 

With the current implementation of game support, I can only, truly know the AppData path once I have the `discovery.path` attribute. 

Example of that here:
https://github.com/Pickysaurus/vortex-hybrid-loadorder/blob/main/src/util/gameSupport/skyrimse.ts#L43


In short, this means that the profile feature will register the wrong files for the load order for Xbox game pass version of the game.

title: Support the Removal of Plugins from \Data

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
This is to address two issues that result from storing a large number of disabled plugins in \Data:

1. Excessive Sort Times - See [LOOT Issue #1370](https://github.com/loot/loot/issues/1370#issuecomment-964132895)
2. Exceeding the Max File Handle Limit

Here are some details:

1. The LOOT issue has been open for a year as of this writing.  At this point I have about 1,400 disabled plugins, and sort time is approximately 3.5 hours.  Removing the disabled plugins from \Data reduces the sort time to a couple of minutes. 
 Other users have reported similar issues and provided additional information, but no specific correction has been suggested yet.  As stated by @Ortham in response to [another issue](https://github.com/loot/loot/issues/1545), "LOOT's sorting performance scaling very poorly with load order size is a known issue.... It's a difficult problem to solve and unfortunately one that I'm not currently enthusiastic/motivated/excited to solve."  In the absence of an official fix from LOOT, the generally accepted way of dealing with this on a user-to-user basis is to remove the disabled plugins from \Data.  It has been reported that at least one mod manager supports this.
2. Exceeding the Max File Handle Limit can be addressed by using Ghosted plugins.  However, LOOT still sorts Ghosted plugins, so issue number 1. would still exist.

A solution I have found that will address both of these problems is to remove the disabled plugins from \Data.  I have been doing this manually, using a batch file to move some 1,400 plugins from \Data to another location.  The result of course is some 1,400 broken hardlinks.  From that point forward each time I Deploy, Vortex urges me to either a.) delete the plugins from the staging folder (which would later require reinstalling 1,400 mods), or b.) restore the 1,400 hardlinks.

In this scenario, the plugins need to be removed from \Data for each sort and for the entire time the game is being played.  When I change profiles (i.e. for general troubleshooting or merged plugin maintenance), the plugins are restored as part of the deploy process.  I then remove them again once Vortex is set back to the primary game profile.

title: Mods are sometimes added to the mods table before they have finished downloading, leading to duplicate entries.
body:
**Describe the bug**
Sometimes when downloading a mod, an entry is created in the mod list under `<No category>`  before the download is complete. This entry only lists the actual filename, no other metadata. Once the download is complete a new entry is created under the correct mod category with complete metadata. This leads to duplicate entries in the mod list. Deleting either entry will remove both entries, making it difficult to manually clean it up and it's easy to delete things by mistake if you're unaware that they point to the same file.

**To Reproduce**
The bug is intermittent so it's not clear to me how to reproduce it other then downloading mods from nexus and see if you end up with an extra entry under `<No category>`.

**Expected behavior**
The mod should not appear in the mod list until the download is complete.

**Screenshots**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/364734/138353616-258adcc3-ff81-4ade-aa04-ecc8e2f30ae2.png)

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version 1.4.16

**Additional context**
1. This is not a case of downloading the same file twice by mistake.
2. This is not a case of shutting down Vortex during a download.
3. This is not a recent bug, it's been around for at least several months.

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
If an installer needs to actually read the contents of mod files to determine if it supports installing a mod, there is currently no way for it to gracefully handle this. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Provide the path to the working install directory (the same path used for `destinationPath` of the `InstallFunc` as an additional parameter to the `TestSupported` function registered by an installer.

Alternatively, provide a way for installers to bail out of the actual install function without failing the whole install (i.e. tell Vortex to try the next supported installer, rather than fail the whole install). Let me know if that's the preferred option and I can raise a separate issue for discussion.

**Additional context**
As it stands the only way to read the files being installed for compatibility checks in the "test supported" step is to get the staging folder, go looking through it for an `.installer`-suffixed directory, then check it against the `files` parameter, just to ensure its actually the mod being installed.

- The drop-down menu would show a list of all deployment methods (not just the currently available ones.

I am aware that the deployment component may require some changes to how deployments are currently registered. Registering a new deployment would potentially require the following data as part of the [IDeploymentMethod](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/vortex-api/blob/f7125e77d1170f2f26865c47fe3b54f79cccd0c7/lib/extensions/mod_management/types/IDeploymentMethod.d.ts):

- Deployment tests - A list of distinct tests for the deployment with the following attributes, where all must pass for the method to be valid:
    - Test name, e.g. "Compatible with ${gameName}"
    - Test information, e.g. "Checks that this deployment type is supported by your chosen game. Note: Where compatibility hasn't been specified by the extension author, Vortex will have a reasonable default set."
    - Test function: Some kind of test that will result in a true/false result. In this example, it would be a check of the game's compatibility attributes and Vortex defaults.
- Note: my example test should probably be the default test which is run in addition to the method-specific ones.

title: Support load ordering of mods for Sims 4

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently Vortex does not have any concept of mod load ordering for Sims 4, all mods are dumped into the folder 
```
../Mods/Vortex Mods
```

This is undesirable when loading scripting mods, which may (and do) override functionality from each other.
Such as the MCCC and Custom Gender Settings (on nexus) which can interfere with what ordering they can modify sim presets (among other more complex things).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Sims 4 loads mods based on alphabetical ordering of folders (in a depth first manner), so it would be desirable to have mods installed in folders reflecting the load ordering -
```
Mods/
|--- 0000_vortex_mod_<mod name A>/
|--- 0001_vortex_mod_<mod name B>/
|--- 0002_vortex_mod_<mod name C>/
...
...
```

**Additional context**

As an example of this, I have made a gist (https://gist.github.com/lgbtqPP/a37ca49b97810fb777e3d045e403ef91) of 5 script mods for sims 4 and am attaching them here precompiled.

They already contain the folder hierarchy, just extract the 5 folders into the Sims 4 Mods directory
```
Mods/
|--- 0000_fclass/
    |--- fclass.ts4script
|--- 0001_test_command/
    |--- test_command.ts4script
|--- 0002_wrapper/
    |--- wrapper.ts4script
|--- 0003_inj_b/
    |--- inj_b.ts4script
|--- 0004_inj_a/
    |--- inj_a.ts4script
```

To test the load order, there is a command available in live mode `inj.otest` which currently should output
```
['iiiii', 'bbbbb', 'aaaaa']
```
The above output says that wrapper from `inj_b` was processed before `inj_a`

Now rename the mod folders for `inj_a` and `inj_b` by switching the 3 and 4 to get `0004_inj_b` and `0003_inj_a` and restart the game and re-run the command `inj.otest` which should now give the output as
```
['iiiii', 'aaaaa', 'bbbbb']
```

[sims4_mod_loading_order_test.zip](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/files/6976714/sims4_mod_loading_order_test.zip)

title: Support extension updates/installation/browsing from non-Nexus sources.

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
After recent changes in author file ownership/control, I'm trying to minimise the files I have uploaded to Nexus Mods, but currently that's the only way for extensions to be browsed in-app or (more importantly IMO) for extension updates to happen without issues.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The way I see it there's two major categories of options: adding additional sources (i.e. GitHub or a configurable endpoint), or providing extensions an API for registering their own updates/sources so that manually installed extensions could still benefit from updates etc.

For the former, if you want to avoid dependence on a single platform, you could always define an API format like how modmeta-db is handled, or even just a variation on the `extensions_1_x.json` format that's less Nexus-specific that authors or platforms could implement. The latter would be less flexible but (at a guess) would require less implementation work.

**Additional context**

I understand this is probably a contentious addition and runs up against similar discussions in the past over the extensions update mechanism but the current situation tightly couples Vortex and Nexus Mods, even for extensions/games/developers who may not be (or want to be) on Nexus Mods.

title: `util.getManifest` is very expensive and can balloon memory usage.

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Describe the bug**
Testing for #8663 eventually led me to the major contributor of the slowdown and memory consumption: `util.getManifest`. This isn't strictly a bug, but might be worth just noting in the tsdoc for the function so that no-one else makes this mistake.

Calling `util.getManifest` is quite expensive: on my machine it takes 150-200ms per call, and since there's a call to `Buffer.toString` somewhere in there, it can also cause a huge allocation of memory if called repeatedly. In my case, I was stupid and was calling it per-mod and that can balloon to the point of crashing Vortex.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Repeat any loop 100+ times (or 1000 if you've got a lot of RAM)
2. Call `util.getManifest()` every loop
3. It will be fairly slow but more importantly the heap will _rapidly_ grow in size

**Expected behavior**
This isn't really a bug, just might be worth throwing a cautionary note in the tsdoc. If you really wanted, a super-short-lived cache could also avoid this, but I think that's probably a bit much for a problem that should only show up if an extension developer is doing things wrong.

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version 1.4.3

title: Suggestion - when mod details is open on the right side, the scroll for the mod list should still be visible

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
The details pane scrollbar covers up the main modlist scroll bar.

**_Details:_**
When viewing your mod list with more entries than frame space available, the overflow is handled with a scroll. This scroll bar becomes increasingly more important as you download more and more mods into vortex. However, when you double click an entry, the details for the mod from the fomod, or guessed at from a server check comes up and hides this scroll bar with it's own. This right side information should not hide the scroll bar for the main mod list. See attached screenshots, with the side bar circled in red.

**_Possible Solution Written Lazily:_**
The simplest solution would be to have the detail pane shifted slightly left to have both scrollbars visible. However, I think that could look a bit weird. Instead, it would probably be cool to have the details pane to the right of the mod list, but not floating. much like the preview pane in the windows explorer on Windows 10 (and earlier). This would position the scrollbar to the left of the details pane, but keep it on the right side of the mod list as expected. The details pane can have its scroll on the right most side of the window. In CSS, it'd be like floating the details pane right, and setting the right margin of the mod list to be equal to the width of the details pane.

**_Steps:_**
1. Open vortex to a game with many mods
2. Navigate to the MODS list
3. Notice right side scrollbar
4. Double click an entry
5. Nnotice the scrollbar is now for the details pane that opened

**_Expected:_**
The scrollbar is visible for both the details pane _and_ the mod list

**_Actual:_**
The scrollbar for the details pane covers up the mod list scrollbar (among other things)

**_Attachments:_**
![Screenshot 2020-12-04 162720](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2062516/101218947-fa07d400-3651-11eb-9e5d-a2436f6f5c36.png)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
