title: Enhance Vortex's submodule instruction to support multi-component/mod archives

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
Currently Vortex cannot support archives containing multiple components/mods unless a singular custom installer is able to distinguish between all components/mods and correctly install these without requiring separate folders/mod entries for each component/mod. So for example games like Blade and Sorcery which use a prefix based load ordering system require a separate mod entry for each component in order for Vortex to be able to assign the prefix correctly whilst also ensuring the game manages to load the mods.

In order to achieve this, the submodule installer instruction could be enhanced to automatically create new mod entries for each submodule (if applicable) whilst also maintaining a bond between the submodules and original mod so that any action made to the original mod is also applied to the submodules (remove/update/etc)

Alternatively, we could simply wait until our mod pack system is released which would allow active mod authors to modify their mod packages and have them work that way - but unfortunately any existing mod archives which act as mod packs where the mod author is no longer active in the community will remain unsupported.

title: API Feature Request: skip extension updates if minimum version is not met

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
If an extension wants to introduce non-backwards-compatible changes, the `IExtensionContext` includes `requireVersion` that will prevent an extension from loading in incompatible Vortex versions. The issue I'm trying to avoid is that a user who doesn't update their Vortex immediately will still have their extension updated to a version that no longer supports their current Vortex version and it will be unloaded.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
To be clear, I haven't been able to fully understand/discern the extension update process so what I'm asking for might be impossible. Based on #6597 it **seems** like there is at least a period of time where both the old extension and new extension are installed. Ideally, when the new version fails to load (since `unloadIncompatible` will unload extensions where the `requireVersion` isn't met), the upgrade could be "aborted" somehow, still leaving the old version in place.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The only other alternative I can think of is moving the Vortex version requirement into an optional field in `info.json` which means Vortex would be able to see incompatible versions before it installed/activated the new version, but that sounds like a lot of work.

**Additional context**
This has come about for two things in BeatVortex: I want to use the new tool parameter stuff (#6629 ), but since people might not have updated to 1.3 when I publish the update, I can't fully rely on it being there without completely breaking existing installs. Likewise, there's upcoming changes in upstream APIs that BeatVortex uses which will require breaking changes.

Ideally, I could publish a new version of the extension that requires a newer Vortex version and old users wouldn't have their games "surprise unmanaged" when the extension gets unloaded on next start, but once they updated to 1.3, the extension would update correctly.

title: Conflict detection for mods using files and directories with the same names.
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
It's not a problem per se. I can avoid that situation by renaming directories in mod file structure.
Let's start with an example, because it will make things easier to understand. Please consider two mods:

- Mod 1 structure `test.bin` is a file:
```
Mod/
 |--test.bin
```
- Mod 2 structure `test.bin` is a directory:
```
Mod/
 |--test.bin/
    |--file1.bin
    |--file2.bin
```
Now, if I install both mod 1 and 2, file conflict is not recognized, neither the files are deployed over each other (well, on Windows you can't overwrite a directory with a file and vice versa). This results in the following error:
![dir_file_deploy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53974091/87656886-5d07d580-c75a-11ea-861a-c1c59671d8bd.jpg)
and in log:
`source=type2, error=EINVAL: invalid argument`

It's a thing, because `test.bin` is in fact an archive, so mods can place both entire archive and unpacked files from that archive.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Recognize mentioned above situation as a mod file conflict.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative is to make sure such situation never happens...

title: Support for Oblivion's INIs being in different places.

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
According to Infernio of Wyrebash. Oblivion can use either the game folder INI or the My Games folder INI based on a INI preference:
> They ship an Oblivion.ini in the game folder that has bUseMyGamesDirectory set to 0. That's a vanilla Oblivion setting that Wrye Bash has always supported, which makes Oblivion (and, by extension, Wrye Bash) not use the My Games/AppData folders and instead stick plugins.txt, saves, BashSettings.dat, etc. into the game folder.

We may want to look into supporting this way of handling Oblivion settings.

title: Extension upgrade throws errors for duplicate action names
body:
**Describe the bug**

Found another `TODO` bug that I've had a lot of trouble reliably recreating. Essentially, upgrades to a currently enabled extension sometimes results in an error dialog complaining about a duplicate action creation that I think is probably coming from [this extension load during installation](https://github.com/Nexus-Mods/Vortex/blob/master/src/extensions/extension_manager/installExtension.ts#L53). Closing the dialog and restarting Vortex manually will sometimes work fine, but sometimes results in two versions of the extension appearing in the extensions list (depending on how the old version was installed).

I think this is partially impacted by how the previous version was installed since just manipulating the `info.json` of a "properly" installed extension to trigger an update doesn't trigger this bug. However, if you manually install a ZIP version of the extension (even downloaded from Nexus), it doesn't seem to recognise it as the same extension and will allow you to *install*, rather than upgrade, the latest version from Nexus Mods, triggering this error.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install an extension that creates an action (Beat Saber Support 0.3.1 would do)
2. Attempt to update that extension
3. You *should* see the error message complaining about a duplicate action (`BS_ENABLE_OCI` if testing with Beat Saber)


**Expected behavior**

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex 1.2.16

**Additional context**

Like I said, this is sorta tricky to replicate even in a clean environment, especially without the ability to install older versions through the Extensions pane, and with how Vortex doesn't seem to match manually installed extensions without Nexus-installed versions of the same extension.

title: actions.updateCategories/update-categories event clobbers existing categories

labels.name: improvement :chart_with_upwards_trend:
labels.description: An issue that improves an existing feature

body:
**Describe the bug**

As always, this could be expected behaviour for a very good reason! I'm just stumbling around in the categories code and noticed something weird.

Emitting an `update-categories` event with an `ICategoryDictionary` parameter results in the `category_management` extension dispatching the `updateCategories` action. The reducer for that action just overwrites any existing categories in the `persistent` state. As far as I can tell, this means that it's impossible for a specific game to have categories populated from more than one source.

This same behaviour also means that an extension using `retrieve-category-list` to populate initial categories (I know it's supposed to be internal, but hypothetically) would completely replace the categories from Nexus Mods provided by `nexus_integration`

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use the Categories dialog to pull Nexus Mods categories
1. Use a toolbar button/global action/whatever to emit `update-categories` with valid params
2. The categories from the event will completely replace the Nexus categories

**Expected behavior**

So I might be expecting this wrong, but I would have guessed that this should *merge* the categories into state, rather than replacing them all.

I understand that it's possible to just use the `setCategory` action to specifically add individual categories, but `update-categories`/`retrieve-category-list` *seems* like it should be the place for adding multiple categories.

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 10
 - Vortex Version 1.2.16

**Additional context**

As always, feel free to tell me I'm doing it wrong :)

title: Bugfix 1.13 beta.4
Making the "Installation corrupted" error message more useful
body:
The current "Installation corrupted" error message lacks useful information and suggests only a blanket approach (reinstall Vortex) that sometimes fails to fix the error. Following that with a more targetted and specific error message will help users diagnose and repair their Vortex installations.

![Screenshot 2024-10-17 073203](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7bea344c-cf55-434d-9cc4-8d746348469d)

1. Add "Quit and check vortex.log for more details" would be a helpful instruction.
2. Even better, add a scrollable text box with the file validation results that are outputted to vortex.log. eg.

```
2024-10-16T23:31:26.796Z [INFO] done file validation 
2024-10-16T23:31:26.796Z [INFO] Files were manipulated {"missing":["resources\\app.asar.unpacked\\bundledPlugins\\game-rimworld\\gameart.jpg","resources\\app.asar.unpacked\\bundledPlugins\\game-rimworld\\index.js","resources\\app.asar.unpacked\\bundledPlugins\\game-rimworld\\info.json"],"changed":[]}
```

See this post for an example of the "Installation corrupted" vortex.log output: https://forums.nexusmods.com/topic/13481082-your-vortex-installation-has-been-corrupted-this-could-be-the-result-of-a-virus-or-manual-manipulation-vortex-might-still-appear-to-work-partially-but-we-suggest-you-reinstall-it/?do=findComment&comment=130472710

I see Reddit and Nexus posts by users with the "Installation corrupted" error, even after reinstall.

Displaying what and why validation failed can only help users prevent repeated corruptions and even some unnecessary reinstallations.

title: Vortex Doesn't Respect/User System Certificates
body:
**Describe the bug**
My computer is on a managed network. The network does SSL decryption. They distribute a CA certificate that I install on my computer. In my browser SSL works fine I just see the installed certificate as the issuer instead of a normal public CA. Vortex seems to not respect/check the system certificate store so Vortex is failing to connect to anything. I was able to find and submit the URLs *.nexusmods.com and *.nexus-cdn.com. Now, downloads sit in the queue and don't actually download.

**To Reproduce**
1. Enable SSL decryption on the network
2. Install the self-signed CA on the computer
3. Try to use Vortex

**Expected behavior**
Vortex should function normally while trusting manually install CA certificatess.

**Screenshots**
![Downloads stuck with URL exceptions](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/33135832-0ea6-4de8-bf35-9b5b576ac679)
![SSL errors](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/56c00c96-1249-46d5-847b-bcc2f5ea5c18)

**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows 11 Pro 23H2
 - Vortex Version 1.12.5

title: Track users getting error 429 (API request limit reached)
body:
### Currently

We have reports that collection users are getting API rate limit error 429 when attempting to install large collections (over 1k) but we don't know how many are being affected. It is possible that users attempting to download multiple collections would also hit this limit.

### We want

To track how many users are getting this issue. We assume you'd have to be a Premium user to hit this limit but we would like to also record their membership level to confirm this.

title: Can't manage file conflicts after mods have been installed
body:
**Describe the bug**
When attempting to resolve a file conflict between mods after they've been fully installed (i.e. not during the installation process), you are only able to select a different option in the drop-down menu (next to the file name in question) for the **first two files** at the top of the list.

Attempting to change options for any files below the first two does nothing (they remain stuck on their original option), but more than that, interacting with their drop-down menus actually affects the options in the first two files instead.

So I can attempt to select a different option for the 3rd, 7th, or 10th file in the list, but instead of affecting those files, their drop-downs affect the options in file 1 and 2 instead, while their own options remain unchanged (incorrect mapping of the drop-down menus?).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to any mod which has more than two file conflicts
2. Right click on it and select "Manage File Conflicts"
3. Try to use the drop-down menus to change to a different option for any files below the 1st and 2nd ones

**Expected behavior**
You expect the drop-down menu next to each file to change the option for that file.

**Screenshots**
Not applicable.

**Platform:**
 - OS: Windows 11
 - Vortex Version 1.12.3

**Additional context**
Downgrading to Vortex 1.11.3 completely resolved this issue. So this bug was introduced at some point after this version.
Also I'm using Vortex exclusively for Skyrim modding (if that's relevant).

title: Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines - Cannot Deploy Mods On Clean Steam Installation
body:
**Describe the bug**
The bundled plugin for Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines cannot deploy mods when managing a fresh Steam installation. This is because the extension includes a mod type for the "Unoffical_Patch" folder, but does not have a write check for that folder. The GOG version of the game apparently comes with this folder included, but Steam does not. 

Because there is a mod type with that folder defined, Vortex will give the deployment error if the folder is not present, which it will not be on a fresh Steam install. 

**To Reproduce**
Start managing VTMB on a clean Steam install. You will get the error that deployment is not possible because of the missing "Unofficial_Patch" folder.

**Expected behavior**
No deployment failures on a fresh Steam install.


SOLUTION:
I have attached updated extension files that will resolve this problem by simply setting the "Unofficial_Patch" folder as the default mod installation folder and including a default tool to launch the game with the required command line argument to use that folder to load mods. 


**Platform (please complete the following information):**
 - Windows 11
 - Vortex v1.12.3
 - VTMB Steam version

[game-vampirebloodlines.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16788055/game-vampirebloodlines.zip)

title: Add an option to manually tell Vortex to sort mods by categories.
body: I just had to reinstall Windows on my PC, and I got hundreds (if not over a thousand) of mods left over from the previous install - some of which aren't on the Nexus anymore - problem is after re-adding them to Vortex the app didn't sort them into categories automatically, and I don't want to have to sort all those mods one by one manually.

title: [Feature Request] Allow Vortex to apply mods to non-executable files
body:
It would be nice to be able to use Vortex to add mods to non-PC games that don't have an .exe file associated with them. For 
example, there's a good few games for the Nintendo Switch on Nexus, but those use the .nsp file format so it's impossible to use Vortex to mod them. It would also be nice to be able to select a folder containing the game's files for games that have been unpacked, but that's far from necessary. In my case, I was attempting to install mods on Final Fantasy 12's Nintendo Switch release, but there were a good number of mods on the game's Nexus page that required Vortex.

title: Updating Starfield
body:
## Research

- ASI Loader needs disabling for Xbox as it's crashing the game.
- Plugins.txt is checked\changed by game on Main Menu load
- `ContentCatalog.txt` is created\updated when a Creation is downloaded (`AppData\Local\Starfield`) and contains metadata for Creations downloaded ingame

## Future

### Creation

- Highlight what is a Creation mod on the load order page instead of what it has now which is 'Not managed by Vortex'. I think this should be reserved for the actual game plugins.

### LOOT

- Add a setting to allow the users to switch between managing the game using the gamebryo extensions, or the current manual dnd load ordering system. A Vortex restart will be needed to switch from one to the other, as the registration calls are all on the main thread. (~2 days of work including testing)
- Add ability to sort plugins using LOOT to the actionbar of the FBLO system. This will _not_ allow us to display loot compatibility messages, unless we want to flood the validation console; and/or are willing to add a custom item renderer. (~up to 1 day of work depending on whether we want a custom item renderer)
- Add migration functionality to disable SFSE/plugins enabler if discovered.
- Add test for deprecated mods?

### Profile specific functionality

- Add independent settings and saves to Starfield profile

title: Remove libxmljs dependency
body:
# Chore

The `libxmljs` library is somewhat unmaintained, and has been causing us issues with our build system for years as it keeps dropping assets.

Currently we only use this library in the Bannerlord extension which we aim to replace/stub in the future.

We should remove this dependency so that it no longer blocks our build process.
